data.title: Amazon.com: The Towers of Trebizond (New York Review Books Classics): 9781590170588: MacAulay, Rose, Morris, Jan: Books
data.meta_description: Amazon.com: The Towers of Trebizond (New York Review Books Classics): 9781590170588: MacAulay, Rose, Morris, Jan: Books
data.text:
Customers find the humor fascinating, quirky, and sad all in one. They also say the characters are well-drawn and the travelogue portion of the work is first-rate.

"...is simply a travelogue set in an earlier time, it is also a fascinating mix of humor and questions many people still struggle with today...." Read more

"...This novel is considered by many to be Macaulay’s finest. I found it interesting, but I must confess that it would have been more entertaining had I..." Read more

"...Humor is in the mind of the beholder, and some of the book was indeed humorous; not in a laugh out loud vein, but rather in a quiet chuckling way...." Read more

"...This book is a wonder: part travelogue, part comedy, it is also, remarkably, a serious commentary on faith and doubt...." Read more

"...It was compulsively readable from the first page, and I read it straight through...." Read more

"...The book has humor and wit, it reads rather matter of factly, without making an obvious intentions, but it is more than about their adventure there..." Read more

"...Macauley is a brilliant writer, and this is a good intro to her work." Read more

"...As I said, this is a somewhat quirky read and not entirely to my liking...." Read more

Customers find the content insightful, magical, and unique. They also say it's a good intro to the author's work.

"...This is more than a travel book and there are some wonderful insights from Laurie...." Read more

"...Macauley is a brilliant writer, and this is a good intro to her work." Read more

"...It is very relevant in the 'emerging church' discussion. This is a challenging read for any who dare to question themselves and their belief system." Read more

Customers are mixed about the storyline. Some find it great and engaging, while others say it's repetitive and goes nowhere slowly. They also mention the writing is acceptable, but the ending seems abrupt.

"...The first stages of the journey are charmingly recounted, but it seemed to be moving along paths maybe a bit too “precious”, through the same..." Read more

"...The only flaw in the book is that the ending does seem rather abrupt." Read more

"...These in particular made the story timeless." Read more

"...The ending is disappointing but the first three-quarters of the book is fabulous. If you are a fan of Amelia Peabody, don't miss this book!" Read more

"...It was written by an eccentric genius and it's a slightly slower read, but a treat just the same...." Read more

"...I found it slower going than camel travel, with long rambling diversions that reminded me of Melville's interminable descriptions of rope...." Read more

"What a slow moving, bizarre book. If it were not for an 'assigned' reading in a book club, I would never get past p. 30...." Read more

Customers find the style of the book stale, anachronistic, and quirky. They also describe it as a period piece that's unsatisfactory.

"...And I believe her “wit” to be a bit anachronistic, perhaps understandable to the British and/or those who lived as adults at the time she wrote this..." Read more
